om7RgLDS0gmMgNUepMv1HQ.text: Very good - not quite up to the best that Pollokshields has to offer but not too far off.  It's got a very "informal" interior and easily transports you back to the days of School Dinners with it's long rows of tables and basic chairs but the vibe is friendly and more importantly the food is excellent.Good grilled Lamb Chops  (although cut a little thinner than I prefer) and Chili Paneer to start followed by Channa Massala and Chicken Saag - it's bring your own bottle too!  There was little sign of the day glo colours you get in some places - everything was spiced and seasoned well, not too heavy on the salt.Nan breads were slightly smaller than I'm used to and we ordered a couple of Roti that didn't turn up so not sure how they were!There's a huge amount of choice in the immediate vicinity but I'd easily come back here for more.

XhYmND_o6R-HRSZYFeBOXw.text: Ha, Where has the original gone? This one is a blatant imposter. Utterly indifferent Lamb Biriyani, limp ugly salad, clueless tourists and clueless incomers packed together in one room. No way will I ever be returning...

_m9NFarlozKkqlFVW_LWcg.text: The ever popular Lahore Kebab House seems to go on from strength to strength. The surroundings are much more civilised than when I first visited this restaurant, some 30+ years ago.The food as always is EXCELLENT and service levels have also improved.I can't push to 5 stars as the restaurant is no longer superb value for money and portion sizes have also reduced.

5orTovLBJkSONViSDR_N3Q.text: Pretty disappointed to be honest.Its reputation coupled with friends recommendations i thought i was in for a treat.Food was average to be honest. Chutneys were poor. The dry lamb and grilled chops were pretty good though...Service was comical, but then you have to expect that to be honest.Just disapointed the food was poor.Not a touch on Tayyabs

bRohvISm5IFnDM7B12ZJ6w.text: Mention Indian food in London and two places come up Tayyabs, and Lahore Kebab House. Finally I made it to the latter, with a group of yelpers for Internet Week. Seems like a strange combination but it actually worked. Spice food, beer and nerds = winner!There is no doubt about it that the food here is wonderful, the meat was wonderfully cooked and the Chana Masala was possibly the best dish to arrive at our table. If you are dining in a large group, this place is perfect. The huge dining hall upstairs makes it a bit like school dinners but in a fun kitsch way. But I wouldn't really recommend taking a date here.It was all a bit greasy to be honest. Not that I mind, greasy adds flavour. (well it does to any dieter - by the way don't come here if you are dieting!)This is a pretty authentic East London Indian experience. A must for ever Londoner, at least once, maybe not it you are vegetarian.

FiBpbChHH-Av_J-yfKnYfw.text: Came here on my friend's recommendation on my first visit to London and they did not disappoint.  I was the first customer on the day and the freshly cooked karahi chicken and the fresh naan left me with an ever lasting impression.  The karahi chicken was very well spiced and together with the naan made for the perfect breakfast before I headed out to see some premier league action. It doesn't get much better than that. Sometimes I think about that day and I hear London calling...

-tsCYeb0M3r8Ic-UWVrBhQ.text: One thing this American heard over and over was that while visiting London, I must be sure to try the Indian food; supposedly it is the world's best. So, what's a girl to do in a land foreign to her own, looking for some good curry and samosas? Yelp! Of course! From my hostel's Internet bar, that's just what I did- and came upon Lahore Kebab House. Choosing this restaurant based on the other 20 reviews was easy- convincing my international party of 8 was not. Luckily for me, my only 2 to-dos while in London were going to Ministry of Sound, and eating Indian food. Due too much fun being had, we missed out on M.O.S., so my friends finally caved in and let me lead them on a few tubes across town- in the rain- to Lahore. Walking there from the tube stop at night in the rain seems a bit sketchy for about 5 minutes. The glowing lettering of the sign was a welcome relief to ease our fear and also to ease our hunger pangs. The restaurant was packed- which was a very good sign. It was mostly Indian and Pakistani patrons, and one group of white people. I can't assume they were English, since my group was comprised of an American, some Canadians, Germans, and an Aussie. We were greeted and seated, and immediately ordered 2 pitchers of mango lassie- thanks to a review I had read. Only one of my German friends had even heard of "lassie" before- but once it was delivered to the table, we all became immediate fans. It's a cold drink, almost like a smoothie- and it's ridiculously good. We ended up going through 3 pitchers for the 8 of us. We had a tiny bit of difficulty understanding our waiter through his thick accent- especially my "foreign" friends. Thankfully, I live in LA, and could pretty much make out any accent, and what he was saying, so I ended up being the main communicator for our group. We each had an entree, shared a huge platter of rice, and devoured almost every appetizer they offer. Everything was SOOO GOOD. It's one of those places where you keep eating, even if you're already full. Yes, I want to try my neighbour's food. Yes, I want another chicken stick. Yes, I need to drink more of this amazing "lassie" stuff. Chicken tikka and chicken masala were popular at my table, but probably only because I could explain those items to my friends, and many of them had never had Indian food before., One of my favourite parts of the evening were the dishes the food was served in. They are the actual little metal pots and tins that the food was cooked in on the stove- meaning, they did not transfer the food to a "pretty" serving plate. It is added to the authenticity of it all, and probably kept the food warmer longer. Another favourite of mine was watching the locals eat. It was obvious that this restaurant was a favourite among them too, and that we were doing something right- since we had just as many plates on our table as they did theirs. When we had all stuffed one last piece of garlic naan into our cheeks for the ride home, we asked for the bill, sad that we could not enjoy some sort of popsicle-type thing that many of the other patrons were having for dessert. I couldn't figure out what they were- but they looked amazing. There was just no more room! The check was extremely reasonable- I think about 15 pounds each... and it was definitely some of the best money any of us had spent on the trip. So yes, if you ever find yourself in London, you need to try the Indian food. It's better than anything I've ever had in LA, and totally worth riding home on the tube smelling of curry!

8JnxlS1tkGdFWgj9zgDtZA.text: The best thing about this place is that you never really have to order. We usually tell our waiter our simple requests like... we want to pay around £10-£15 each, we like lamb, we don't want chicken, we want samosas, etc. They easily do vegetarian as well. They bring out whatever they want and it's a full three course meal! Everyone leaves the table full and content.P.S. BYOB! All the local liquor stores stock top Indian beers just for LKH!

7I711zkF7k4Rv-TaDCH32w.text: bring on the ghee!  i had put in my name and told a 20 minute wait.  i was ushered into a stark open waiting room where complimentary papadum and raita keep you occupied until your dinner.  my friend was late so i ended up waiting an hour for her.  the host never did call my name and said he had forgot, but i wasn't too peeved with the continuous groups of diners entering.  he said to let him know when my companion arrived and he would seat us.  BYOB so plenty of off license spots across the street and next door purchase beer and wine.  i ordered my tried and true chicken tikka masala and a garlic naan.  my more discerning indian pal went with the lamb curry special.  mine was spicey and i was sweating bullets.  my tolerance for spice is not high so might be fine for others.  my friend said her lamb curry was spicy as well.  so craig m's certainly correct on the spice factor.  the service was a bit all over the place.  food was served quickly, but getting the bill was another story.  it seemed like multiple waiters were at one table sorting the credit card machine as the manager was ordering about.  so more like 3.5 stars but i round up for the eats and the thumbs up from my indian pal on choice of eats.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. tikka chicken masala

PTLQeycKX80vncYH-8gpog.text: If you ever need a chilled out place for a group meal this place is it! Make reservations before had if it is a massive entourage of 8+ ppl.  It would be hard to find a seat otherwise after 7pm.For a super busy place the service is really good.  The staff is attentive and will make their best effort to get to you in a reasonable time.  They are not rude either, they won't try to push you out  just to turn tables.  I love the lamb chops here, nice and spicy but not enough spice to make you cry... so it is really enjoyable.  If you miss out on the butter chicken that is fine because you are not missing much here.  The bring your own booze factor is great too.  I bought a case of cobra beer 12 large bottles in, and put it on the table... no one complain because it's the norm here.  Good atomsphere and good food.

qhYoJ2dbawGdLyFS15UwIw.text: Lahore Kebab House did not disappoint. With all the reviews this place has we had to try it on our vacation. London had some of the best Indian food that we've ever had. Come prepared for the spicy curries and the succulent lamb chops! Don't forget to BYOB!!! We ordered:Chicken with onion and peppers curry: Spicy and deliciousGrilled Lamb: A must try!Vegetarian curry: Perfect balance of spice and vegetable flavor

VrW55PVpC64muH8WhsI9KQ.text: Forget Brick Lane. Why bother being hassled and overcharged when you can be respected and fed incredibly delicious and reasonably priced curry? Lahore is everything you could every want. BYOB, fast service, a plethora of dishes, I could go on all day. So the next time you're in the mood for a curry, man up and head to Whitechapel.

yZLtWlNWrOTHXnyraWSR8g.text: Amazing food! The Asian cuisine is just excellent!  Literally everything on their menu is just yummy!

51eP656sD1H6idb8w7tKmw.text: I went to Lahore for yelp's Internet week curry night. Definitely a fun and interesting experience.The food is ok, but what makes this place different is it's atmosphere. It seemed like it is usually packed, and the long hall room dining tables upstairs makes you feel as though you found an authentic slice of India. I tried the chicken, lamb, and green potato curry. The lamb chops were good too. Watch out tho, it's spicy here. There's not much to say about the service because this place is so busy the waiters have to serve you on the run, but this doesn't matter because between talking to new people over the din of the restaurant while trying to extinguish the fire in your mouth with beer you'll be having too good of a time to care. Lahore is more of a "get stuck in there" kind of place than a conventional "hi, my name is Francois and I'll be your waiter this evening". Don't dress up, in fact the curry stains badly, just come as you are and be ready to have fun trying great Indian food in an authentic Indian setting.

Ru8URb2aHF08X-RwV3eH5Q.text: An awesome Pakistani restaurant. I'm originally Pakistani, and I'm a huge fan of Lahori food (a lot of my family is based in Lahore and so you know, I know my shit). It's best to go between Wednesday and Sunday inclusive. This is when they serve an AWESOME Pakistani dish called "nehari". It's so great that if I try and describe it I would be doing it severe injustice. It's quite busy so you may have to wait a bit to go in (I'm not 100% sure if they take bookings so you might want to check - I live 5 minutes away so I just showed up after calling to check if it was busy). The staff are friendly and mean well but in busy times it may be difficult to get their attention. It's also a bring-your-own-booze restaurant so those of you inclined that way may like that - I don't drink so I wouldn't know how much value that adds to your dining experience. Also make sure you order the saag alu, chicken and seekh kebabs, and a kebab roll (in addition to the nehari of course!)

NJachxYyVULvoyUj4KYNvA.text: Simply the best Kebab I've ever had!!!! And not just the meat that was awesome, their Naan and rice were both exceptionally great as well !!! Definitely gonna come back and try the rest of their menu!

b7ijloxIDvNC2OWKfwQ43Q.text: Absolute satisfaction. The briyani and lamb curry on the bone and lamb chops and.... well just about everything... was.. burrrrrrrpppppp... delicious! Even the plain Naan bread was good.. There are a few unsatisfactory reviews about the decor, service and the spiciness of the food. Fine. This place, you go there for the food. Not the decor. Service is basic..You get your food, drinks and bill. Thats all you need. You want great service and decor, go to a Michelin restaurant. And for the spice, well thats how curries should be - Fragrant, full of flavour and spicy. It originated from Asia.. Duh..  One wierd thing is that the drinks always comes really late to your table. Every time I had to remind them. And it was just not for my table. It was almost every table. But they are smart.. Very smart.. I think they want you to start drinking the bottled water on the table first. Very cheeky tactic but I have not succumbed. (Pats self of the back)After every visit I had to unbutton my jeans. Tip : Wear a baggy top!

lv3HVazohdl7-fDyO-QMZg.text: Lahore Kebab House is one of these hole in the wall joints which MUST be visited by lovers of kebabs and indian food. Dont go looking here for the ambience or quality service. Just concentrate on the food and enjoy it. It may be on the oily side, but hey..indulge yourself once a while. You can bring your own drinks as well. A decent meal for 2 will cost around £25

llHpNGZRJ9iZwEIIdeUMCw.text: I'm still confused why people are so obsessed with this place. Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing, but both my boyfriend and I were really disappointed with the quality of the food given the reviews we'd read. It was fine, but nothing special. I can say I don't recommend the kofta or paneer tikka...

DEnJyIdpG8ZzWTUb4QW2MA.text: Only been here once, but it's some of the best (and fastest) Pakistani I've had. Had I known there was haleem available on weekends only (and that it's amazing here), I might have come back. Or at least come on a different day. This restaurant is essentially like getting stall food at an open market, just inside four actual walls. It's quick, inexpensive and somehow more gratifying than a fine dining experience with the same food would ever be. Can't comment on the curries, but the kebabs are incredible! I've never seen anyone pay such intimate attention to a tandoor, and the effort pays off. If I lived down the street from this place, I think life might be complete!

aNCmRuUKy8AvCARZeV3TcQ.text: Oh LKH!  This was one of my favorite places in London a few years ago.  Now, not so much.  Either they've gone downhill or I've outgrown what they do.Let me start with the chicken tikka: it used to be wonderful.  Properly blackened yet juicy and amazingly flavorful.  Now, it's an orange goop, too pink on the inside to be appetizing.Seekh kabab: Nonono!Lamb chops: decent, but too toughPalak Paneer: Why has it started tasting stale?Chicken Karahi: Somedays this is actual chicken karahi, other days you might order a karahi and get the generic chicken curry.Mango Lassi: For the fake tin-alphonso lassi, decent.Maybe they have started catering to a mixed audience and strayed from what they did well.  Weirdly, the service has also become much less friendly.Consistency is really a problem: on some days and on some dishes they still hit a six, other days the food is plain hard to eat.

L4DSumhUTd_25wbdwpkyUA.text: I'm going to keep this review short, as I'm not going to cheapen curry nirvana with words. This is (though debatabley) the be-all, end all curry experience and if you ever find yourself in London you simply have to go. Everything I ate -- and boy, did I ever eat -- was outstanding. At our table was Chicken Tikka Masala, Sag Gosht, Sag Paneer, Chana Masala, Chicken Biryani and assorted naans as well a few other dishes that though tasty, I'd never seen before. Oh, and the Friday lamb chops, of course, were quite good. So here's the thing, if you are used to Indian food being a certain way, you may need to get over that fact. You may find this stuff slightly different (it is actually Pakistani, after all), but I promise, once you put aside your expectations your taste buds are in for a fun ride.Remember to go to the Off License next door to grab a few 40s of King Fisher (or whatever the Brits call 40 ounce bottles of beer). Lahore does not serve beer and wine, but will happily allow you to consume what you bought next door. And if you like Bollywood music videos, you're in for a treat, they have them playing on the flat screens. I always think that adds something, but who doesn't like a movie where they break out in song for no reason?

micPQ5kEbnhp3lTAL_aiFw.text: Went here for some late night dining and was NOT disappointed. With 7 of us, we got since lamb chops, biryani, saag paneer, lamb and chicken rolls, various curries and naans (there's a sweet one that I absolutely LOVED and one in olive oil and herbs, but forget the names of them). We filled ourselves plenty and it only ended up costing £10 each! Plenty of seating available so we didn't have to wait unlike a nearby establishment that had a massive line.

KuN_Vr7AAUwtY5P2d4JaMA.text: Typically, I'm in London 4-5x a year for work.  Often, on my last evening in town, I'll go out for some beers with the lads.  Last time, one of my mates suggested a curry after we put down a few pints at the pub next to his office in Canary Wharf (Henry Addington, solid spot, but this review isn't about that).  So, onto the DLR to Shadwell, a short walk, stopped at the off-license on the corner and onto Lahore.  If you're looking for a beer with dinner, stop at the corner, as Lahore does not serve, though are happy to let you drink whatever you decided to bring with.  Get a 40 of Cobra.  Goes very well with the curry.Between the 3 of us, we put down a pile of food, including Paneer Tikka, Onion Bhajia, Chicken Jalfrezi, Lamb Chops, and some sort of kebab I can't recall.  All of it was fantastic.  Even the fish curry that one of the guys wanted was good, and I'm not a fish guy.  The naan was tasty, and quite fresh too.  I enjoyed the garlic naan.  I also sampled a bit of the mango lassi.  Very nice.No wait, caught some football on the tv, and service was quite fast too.  I'll be back.

m5VI9YuH-JdhuuRjcrpstw.text: Lahore is solid curry, much better than anywhere you'd eat on Brick Lane and worth braving the queue. I came here with a visiting friend after taking another out-of-towner to Tayyabs the week before. I preferred Tayyabs for the same goal -- getting off Brick Lane, finding good curry and a fun BYOB atmosphere.We ate vegetarian here, so I can't speak for their meat dishes, but the chana masala and mixed veg curry were good. Not blow your mind good, but "I'd eat that again" good.Try it. You'll probably like it.

wN4uoXLjvF3mtGov7OVGdQ.text: I really like this place, the staff are friendly the food is authentic and fresh and you can bring your own drink. It has a very lively atmosphere almost any day of the week the portion sizes are generous and it is very reasonably priced. The only negative I would put is that sometimes I've gone and the food was completely delicious, sometimes just good. It's still definitely worth going!

nkCJbfIVGTl--QTHO-prLQ.text: Great food should be your sole reason to go there. I wouldn't expect anyone giving them below 5 stars for food reasons particularly on a comparative scale.

O3-jl0qjfyKONZcJTRhPWg.text: Lahore Kebab house is kind of the place I go when I want a curry but: i) I'm too lazy to make one properly (or I'm not at the rents), ii) I'm not lazy enough to use that sneaky bottle of Patak's in the fridge, and iii) the good takeaway place doesn't deliver. You go here for the relatively cheap food and the abundance of space (massive canteen style dining upstairs). You don't however go here if you like to have the waiter be more attentive than an autistic zombie as trying to get there attention is an exercise in futility. You rock up, you order food, they toss it on the table, and you never see him again until you've begged to pay the bill. Or maybe that was just us.Unfortunately, it's just not cheap enough to justify it. Tayyabs is just a little further away and only slightly pricier but miles ahead in terms of quality of location, service, and dare I say flavour. I'm not anti-Lahore, just a bit disappointed it didnt' live up to my rosy memories of Lizzie's curry night there as my first UYE. But, it does have tvs and the game on so if you are looking for an Indian pub, Lahore is exactly what I imagine it would be.Oh, and careful about the toilets. They are dirtier than the average one in India and that's saying something.

SCcYRr7ah1LtjUtYqsjw2g.text: This place is awesome. Great food, amazing taste. I was in london for a week and was longing for some good indian food. My friend bought me here and it was amazing. Their chilli paratha and dal was too good. The food is so delicious, I kept saying wow everytime I tasted another bite.

yCvQKaNidbgbDSEU403X5w.text: 1) Lahore is BYOB. You get to drink Cobra on the cheap.2) Lahore has a massive upstairs dining area so long waits are not too much of an issue.3) Lahore shows football on the TV while you eat.4) Lahore has about 13 different vegetarian options on the menu5) Lahore's food tastes VERY good.

zpstQRJhrqOQNY6CvLvWoQ.text: A fantastic BYOB Indian. The queues are long, but worth it.The food is cheap and is full of flavour! Be warned though, it is super hot!This place has taken over from Tayyabs as my favourite place for a curry!

jAWI7Mhi6-XdpB1eRk7q7w.text: Hello, my name is Kevin and I'm a fatty. I've been struggling with my cravings since I discovered food nearly thirty years ago. Would anyone be willing to be my sponsor?---I could make a meal out of Lahore's spicy lamb chops. In fact, I might as well have, because we ordered two portions for two people, and it was enough to be filling.... but then I would have missed out on the gluttony of butter chicken, saag paneer, and fluffy naan that ensued.All this, washed down with some frosty Kingfisher, obtained around the corner at the local offie ( which probably does most of its custom as a function of its proximity to Lahore...).I love that the men's toilet offers your choice of four different hand soaps, and yet I still see people walk out after peeing sin lavan los manos. Didn't y'all learn in school that washing your hands is the best protection against illness?! Not okay.It's a testament to the nomminess of the grub that 1) I'm willing to return, 2) I'm willing to overlook other diners' unsanitary behaviour, and 3) I'm willing to haul over here from Knightsbridge after an afternoon ogling the goods at Harrods.Respect.

hBixCjnnpyL2l-uZitCLSg.text: This is my favorite restaurant in the whole word. I love spicy food. Whenever I visit London, I know this is a must. The food is topnotch. The service is quick. It's a BYO. I love it!

-WvG-T0K4a36NV2zlVbdhw.text: Unbelievable curry!BYOB!Not gourmet in any stretch; rather, equiv to top notch street food, and priced as such.I try to get here at least once during every London visit.I can eat 10 of their lamb chops like they were indian (pakistani) white castle sliders!

jbyo2COjPaPboeBPnXF5Vg.text: Why is this bhaaji so soggy?  Wait, why is my mouth on fire?!What is this? Roti? Are these the naan?  Why are they so hard and sad?Where are the poppadoms?Mmm... paneer.  Um, this sag is overcooked.And SPICY. Ohmygod where is the water?!Ooo, chana masala!  [Cough, cough, sputter]Ghee, why?  Why is there so much ghee?Umm... where is the rice?Ah, there's some vegetable rice.[Bleurgh]I'll just sit here, shall I?Ah, some pilau rice, good.. . .Thank god, mango lassi.  Just feed me mango lassi next time.__________________________________Moral of the story: don't even bother coming to Lahore Kebab House if you're a vegetarian.  Seriously.

LdoFWwugO7RWAKkXrsG0nQ.text: A fall from grace.Why does eveything have to be so damned spicy? I just don't understand it. Even the raita on the table had a kick, and that's a minty yoghurt dressing. You can imagine what the actual spicy dishes were like.The service was really quite terrible. The drab surrounds and canteen stlye set up were almost endearing on my last visit, as long as you had a friendly and informed waiter who tended to your needs. Our guy just wasn't interested.Such a shame, as this place used to be held in high esteem. Now there seems little point in braving the inevitable queues.There were two redeeming features though - the BYOB is a great deal and those lamb chops are delicious (if not a little meagre).

372RVDuXSiJjEwCvwKISiw.text: The food here was pretty good and reasonably priced. We had the lamb and chicken kabab along with a chicken tikka masala dish. The latter wasn't the best that I had. I still recommend this place if you are looking for reasonably priced and good pakistani food.

oLN4_YWy6n1I5KfNNi-8xQ.text: One of the legends of the cheap food scene; their lamb chops are to die for and it's a bring your own so no arguing over who ordered the wine! Service can be a bit shoddy, but the food makes it just about forgivable. Word of warning though; don't come here looking for romance or a peaceful dinner. When it's full you'll have to put your lip reading skills to great use. For my money and taste, this is much much better that Tayabbs.

ZCP1QvqCdFi2rnFaWXKPSA.text: Lahore is lovely, and I will certainly return often. But I am a loyal lover. (Just ask my fiancé who still gets to hear about my high school boyfriend more often than he'd like.) I just don't get over love easily and since Tayyabs captured my heart early on, I'd still have to say it ranks higher.Here's the low-down: you're going to get delicious food at both Lahore and Tayyabs. Our feast of biryani, tarka, samosa, bhajia, paneer, aloo, chops, masala, curry, jalfrezi, among other dishes was stunning. So if you're debating between Lahore and Tayyabs, it comes down to these questions: 1. Do you want to sit down within ten minutes and not have to deal with hordes of pushy people?2. Does ambiance mean little to nothing to your overall dining experience? (Think high ceilings, bright overhead lights, yellow walls and cafeteria style seating)If you answered YES to both of these questions, then Lahore is for you. They skip the "experience" of a smokey dark underground curry house in favour of quick, delicious, accessible food. (This also then skips the horribly long wait that inevitably includes arguing with the host and being man-handled by the comers and goers.)Funnily enough, I almost missed the above experience during my visit to Lahore. Apparently, I'm a sucker for those hard-to-get, bad boy curry houses. Figures. Once you've fallen in love, and fallen hard - even if your next partner is stunning, beautiful, kind, generous... that first love will always haunt you.

wHU-1uOIpghEdcmOSwWNQQ.text: Every time I go to one of these 'amazing' curry houses, that people on Yelp rave about, and queue up for, I want to jump up and shout 'The Emperor is naked y'all'. Because Lahore certainly is another candidate for the Emperor's New Clothes award, a restaurant that is not that good but inexplicably has generated a lot of kudos. When we first arrived I thought we were in the wrong place. If it looks like a dodgy kebab house and smells like a dodgy kebab house, then don't be surprised when it is. Inside it looks like a hospital canteen, with wide-screens on the wall showing the football. While I'm eating. Super. The menu isn't very big, but that can be fine if the food is amazing. It isn't. I thought everything was greasy and overly spicy. The naan bread was not good, they brought plates of dips and salad but no popadoms. Why? Where are my popadoms? (I realise I have no idea how to spell poppadoms, neither does Firefox, do you?) The lamb chops that this place is famous for were distinctly unimpressive and fatty. It seemed like they just masked the mediocrity with a lot of spices. I'd never go back. Maybe for the mango lassi. And if you were paying.

Nr_vxkXKqQP_X4zTmM3oCQ.text: Don't go here for the ambience, but if you want some excellent cheap curry/kebab that you can scarf down with a pint from the off license next door, this place will do the trick. It's really busy but they usually have tons of space so shouldn't be a problem. Friendly service. Great food. Amazing prices.

I7ncs37xhQvKRW-7XwFMMQ.text: Honestly, we didn't enjoy this place as much (maybe half as much) as 90% of the other reviewers. It could be because we didn't do the lamb. Nor order a lassi. Who knows?For my friends last evening in London, she wanted 'Brick Lane' curry. Well for one, especially to those Trip Advisor reviewers, this is NOT Brick Lane. As a matter of fact, it's 10 minutes away and corners the high street and an alley.Large restaurant. Very busy. Lots of tables all covered with white. White walls. Definitely a place where you bring the ambiance. And decorations.We went pretty standard (and steered clear of red meat after a weekend in Romania and spiced inced meat stuffed into everything). Chicken tikka masala and Butter chicken. Garlic naan. Pilau rice. And sag paneer (a fave of mine). The chicken tikka masala came 1 minute after ordering. They must have a large vat they spoon it from. Eventually followed the rest of the food. Naan and rice the last two brought out. The sag was decent. Which really sucked because I LOVE sag paneer and it's such a standard, I didn't think they could screw it up. The chicken dishes were ok, definitely spicy hot. We even asked a 2nd time if one dish was actually the butter chicken. Really don't think it matched what we're previously ordered elsewhere.It took a while to get someone for a check. The second we put our credit cards n the machine, three men came in our way to clear our table. We came. We ate. We over-ordered. We didn't overpay. We walked away thinking meh. Next time, it's Brick Lane - any joint - for us. Nothing special here.

1cARZK2GIyzNzDCdxjejWQ.text: For those of you who like a side of Champions League play with your lamb chops and butter chicken, it's worth mentioning that if a match is on it's likely being shown at Lahore.After leaving a pub at halftime, we came here for dinner and discovered the game on telly in full view of our upstairs table. Score!

Nv-tViee0Vu5i_5HBsz25w.text: The food here is awesome. The service has growth opportunity. I ordered the Friday special. It was Lamb Chop curry. The sauce was spicy and flavorful. The naan and sweet lassi was also pretty good. Actually, make sure to order one of lassis because you'll need it's anti-spicy effects when your mouth is on fire from the curry. That is all for my wisdom for now.

d23JflZAdigmfaRxb_UXSQ.text: The service, the food, the price, all top notch! The lamb kebabs are succulent and will melt in your mouth. Best tandoori in London!

MrPZojpWbhcCLFg9mZkdYQ.text: Looks like hole in the wall. Food was below average. Everything we ordered was lacking flavor. The restroom was very dirty. I was born and raised in India, and this food is far from what good Indian food tastes like. Do not recommend.

J2DnUF1GK5M14ZgYvtz68g.text: This Is an amazing Restaurant, Lahore is the Second largest City of Pakistan I was Told. This Original Restaurant Is A Jewel to the Locals.. Amazing Home Made Taste Food. I Couldn't get Enough of their variety!! Is a Must if you Visit London UK.Ask What are the Ingredients to each plate, they Like Explaining it to you and trust their opinions, It worked for me. I Got the Biryani Lamb Chop with Garlic Nam (Flat Bread), Chicken Korma, Karahi Paneer Tikka. This Place it's Awesome. In Flavor, Presentation, Cleanliness  and Their Staff are Super Friendly.Home Run!!!

T2_RBuhdYxjTGxAf7uwB2g.text: Food was delicious, had amazing bhindi with chilli Nan, serving was very fast, waiter were kind. I still got food at 00:30o'clock.Disadvantages: they don't serve beer and the place was very loud

orEduco7ESFqBu_wf33KYA.text: We had planned to eat at another Indian restaurant in East London, however it turns out that the restaurant was closed at the time we wanted to visit.  A local, noticing that we seemed a bit confused, kindly stopped and asked us if we needed help with directions.  We explained our situation and the gentleman provided us with a recommendation to this restaurant, which was a short walk from where we were situated.  After getting directions from him, we were on our way.  All things considered, our lunch in east London worked out great!Luckily, we did not encounter a wait at the restaurant.  I put the responsibility of ordering in the hands of my friend, who was well-versed in Indian cuisine.  We ended up with a great selection of chicken and vegetarian dishes, along with plenty of garlic naan.  The prices seemed quite fair considering the quality and quantity of food.  The servers were attentive and were great at bringing out more naan within a short period of time.  I enjoyed the chicken tikka masala and sag paneer.  It was a wonderful surprise given our rough start for Indian food in East London.

yXVmvB_04igKKZ483eWl7w.text: Rate the lamb chops in here far more than Tayyabs. The rest is all ok, solid curry and other classic dishes. Service as to be expected but the prices are good. Go to place in Whitechapel.

mR0a_g9mzfIENk_cmv24CA.text: This place is simply A.M.A.Z.I.N.G!!! best food I had in London. Triple back flip and big hand: I'm in love! I could eat here every night. Highly recommend the lamb chops, the bhindi / ladyfingers, shish kebab, plain naans. These recommendations mean: you HAVE to order them. And if you are not in London, hop on a plane and try them, dammit!We ordered so much and everything was just perfect. Big hand to the chefs! Love u guys!Don't be put off by the simple interior, this is no classy I-only-eat-organic-salad-with-gold-sparlkes design place. This is where the love for food was born and it still lives there.

wYNkd89Z4ou7ODQSkXJ49w.text: Lahore is a London institution; a cheap Indian BYO in a city that could is painfully limited in terms of BYO offerings. We came around 6 on a Saturday so the restaurant was still fairly empty when we arrived, but by the time we left there was a queue out the door and the whole place had taken an entirely different atmosphere. First of all the venue is huge; looks something like a cafeteria, and on the left side there are glass windows through which you can see the kitchen but that are quickly steamed over. I was told to go big on the appetizers and to definitely order the grilled lamb chops; they did not disappoint. The chicken tikka was good too but the big draw of the place is the atmosphere: go with a big party, bring a lot of wine, and take it for what it is: young, cheap London at its best

4msWZrS_utAwYBDl-n45Rw.text: I know everyone's been raving about Lahore, but I'm not a *huge* fan of the place.  Cheap food, yes.  Quality?  I will admit that I'm probably not the best judge of Indian food, but its alright. Service?  Pretty much tossed out the window!We were trying to flag down the waiter to place our order for about the past 20 minutes.  During that time, we also ordered still water, and a jug of mango lassi - both which had to be repeatedly asked for.And its kinda funny - you ask one guy for something, and he delegates it to someone else, who delegates it to someone else, and it gets lost in the jumble. I understand that some people say that with cheap food, you get what you pay for.  I'd probably go here rather than the Brick Lane specials, but I would rather go somewhere else where I could actually get some service. We ordered 3 mains, a jug of mango lassi, 3 naan and rice, and I *think* 3-4 appies, which came to about £75 (25pp) - maybe its my Asian roots, but for that type of service, I dont think the price is cheap enough!

6jqeRD4-G0cYe3NoOftZDQ.text: * To be clear, this is an Indian food restaurant* Food is cheap* Ability to see into the kitchen is neat* Servers don't really speak English & are rude - unwilling/able to answer questions* Extremely loud* Everything felt sticky and the room was dimly lit* Not the worst Indian food I've ever had, but it certainly wasn't good* Good garlic naan - moist and not burnt

LlrOrHMZb9DDaggwJLvwWg.text: No question about the tastiness and freshness of the food.  We got the Wed-Sun special of Chicken on the bone curry and lamb biryani.  Both were excellent, spicy, tasty, and moist.  The garlic naan was good and hus like the pandoori roti.We had to keep asking for things and help b/c the waiter never came up to us otherwise.  Would go back and try some more stuff.Had the traditional Indian dessert of seeds and stuff wrapped up in a leaf as we walked out.  Really freshens the breath!

GibugDd05pioxCxfBD78gg.text: We visited this place based in our taxi drivers recommendation but I've to say we were very disappointed. I think the place is known more for their curries. We ordered the seekh kababs, lamb chops and chicken Tikka. Only the land chops were good. The rest, were not authentic in taste. Seekh kababs were almost tasteless.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Seekh kabab
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Seekh kabab
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chops

pj7GROEXxN246iSQmLOIiQ.text: I pretty much go here if Tayyubs has too much of a queue as it's only down the road. But Lahore has been around for generations. It's exactly like Lahore though has more of a stripped down décor and less buzzing vibe. The starters of sizzling chops and chicken are the thing to get. And of course if not full share a curry with fresh breads. It's dirt cheap too, so won't break the bank.

2mtCN748QZyEnH1cXFPV4w.text: Wanting to try a kebab while in London, my online research led me to Lahore. Having nothing to do on a weekday evening, I braved the 20+ stop tube ride from my hotel in far west London to Aldgate East and after a short walk, I was queuing amongst other Pakistani food seekers. However, finding a table for 1 is super easy so I didn't queue for too long.I started with a couple of tasty kebabs and then tried a main dish. I wish I had more patience and had tried more dishes but everything that went into my mouth was tasty. You may end up leaving smelling like kebabs so plan your evening accordingly. However, it's nothing that airing out the clothes won't cure.

K5XW-qE0ohAZHBF6ivo80w.text: Imran and his people offer an amazing journey through India and Pakistan at Lahore Kebab House. The lamb kebab is perfectly spiced and the thin pork chops delish. Thank you for introducing us to new things including lahori kulfi. After making sure our table was dish to dish with food, Imran excused himself for Ramadan. Peace.

nFdS-k8GFp2Xhk9TvYKF-w.text: It wasn't bad but it wasn't as amazing as I was expecting after all the hype. Except for the lamb chops. It had a great buzzy vibe though which always adds to the experience. The lamb chops were outstanding. As were the poppadoms but the curries and the naan was really average. The pilau rice was just boiled rice with carrots and peas which I found unusual, wasn't to my taste. And the butter chicken was spicy! Loved the BYOB aspect of it though.I wouldn't go back, I still stand by Tooting being the winner for curries. Cheaper too!

j9z_DCWpbOsY_9G6Y8yqFA.text: Really impressed by the lamp chops here - thanks to all the other yelpers who commented and recommended on this dish! I ate the lamb chops as an entree (a bit too spicy for me, but asked for lemon to dilute the taste of the rub, and also had it with yogurt) and the since it was a Friday special, also got the lamb chop curry. But I'm starting this review all topsy-turvey!So, to start from the beginning, our rental place is in the Whitechapel area, and when I put in curry house in Yelp as the search term, this place and Tayyab came up tops. Tayyab didn't have a booking available for 7:15, but this place did, so lucked out! Because when we got here, the lines were starting and we were ushered right into the dining room, past some other people waiting for free tables. and I felt a little sorry for them cause the smells were mouth-watering and none of that stale oil or burnt curry powder smell was emanating, so I had high hopes for the food (which were fulfilled!) After being seated in a corner table, got tap water, and raita plus a lovely salad of onions, tomatoes, and lettuce and then for entrees we split a samosa (decent) and the lamb chop as an entree dish. We got like 8-9 chops, perfectly seared, thinly sliced and bursting with flavour. Loved it! Then I ordered lamb chops curry with a garlic naan, my mum got palak paneer with wholemeal roti, and my cousin got butter chicken with garlic naan as well. I really loved the flavours of my dish - it was meaty pieces of lamb, swimming in a sea of prefect spices and because the lamb was on the bone, I got some bone marrow mixing its umami flavours in the curry sauce, so just utter deliciousness in each bite. I liked my cousin's chicken and re: my mum's pick, I liked the palak more than the paneer (a rarity for me), but for my palate, the lamb here totally is the star.I was full so didn't get any dessert but mum and my cousin got gulab jamun (2 pieces in a serve). I had a taste and it was decent, but am not a gulab jamun girl - my cousin and mum were very happy tho'  and reckoned it was home-made. I ended the meal with a pan (oh yeah! Perfect ending). The total was £42 between the three of us, so def great value for money and really good service too! Def recommend and hope to be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. The full smorgasbord
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Naan and roti
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chops curry

o91xafuqajhp15GEAisqmw.text: Old story. Father passes successful business to entitled, Millennial son. I have made it a point to come to LaHore every time I am in London over the last 15 years. We've had big parties and raved to many friends about this formerly amazing establishment, not to mention having them join us.My business associate and I went for dinner. The onion bhajia was soggy and tough. The Tandoori Prawns were so overcooked, we sent them back. The next round was a bit better, but not much. The chilli nan had no kick. Bland! It used be to our challenge of who could eat one as it was so hot. We paid our check and left before ordering dinner.My business associate is the person who introduced me to LaHore 15 years ago. He asked for the owner and the owner's son came over. The son would not look at us and was quite rude with his attitude. Yes, my associate was furious and embarrassed about our experience and did drop the "F" bomb but apologized quickly. The owner's son could not let that go. Respect is earned, not a privilege. As we left, the son said to my associate, "We have thousands of customers, we don't need you." Need I say more?Our waiter was new and tried his best to make the situation right. His efforts were appreciated. After hopping into a taxi, the driver knew all about the situation. The staff and particularly the kitchen, has no respect for the son. The word on the street is that LaHore is done. It's only a matter of time. The staff evidently want a real restaurant manager but the father is determined to stand behind his son and not face the reality that his son is just not cut out for this work given his upbringing. Bringing in a serious restaurant manager may save this landmark. If not, it will continue to go down the tubes. Just read the recent reviews. So sad. As for us, we say thank you for 15 years of memorable dining! We are sad to say "Farewell!"

MFb3P4i8XE6xO4t3JGhmTQ.text: Abysmal service at Original Lahore Kebab House marred what could've been a delicious and pleasant meal otherwise.We were seated quickly during the dinner rush, and our orders were whisked away promptly. The food emerged in a timely fashion; the large restaurant was bustling for sure with what seemed like lots of families and locals. As for wetting our whistles, we ignored the non-free water bottle plopped down but instead both ordered mango lassis. You can get them in a jug if you are addicted but it'd be advisable to have more than two diners for a jug. The lassis were fruity and not to sweet; we were happy with them.We had ordered sag paneer and lamb korma. They were both on the spicy side but I managed to get thorough the flames okay. All right, it wasn't that bad, I kid. Very flavorful and fair portion sizes. The garlic nan was slightly rubbery and had sprinkles of cilantro which I dislike. Nice rice though. You have to order nan and rice separately from the mains.The bathroom was okay but if you don't have to use it, that's probably for the best.Paying was an ordeal. At first, the two of us were sitting around, obviously done, and no staffer did anything. So we asked one person. No check. Another person. No check. Minutes slipped by. There was probably another request in there that fell onto deaf ears. We were ready to pay for nearly 30 minutes. Finally, a pair of diners seated next to us well after we had started eating happened to ask for the check, so we were able to piggyback our bill request onto theirs. Finally. It was like pulling teeth. I want to give you money, why are you thwarting us?I left feeling irked that we had wasted a lot of time sitting around. And I felt really guilty that I had suggested this place too. Whoops. What a shame though, since Lahore's food was actually good. Oh well, two stars it is.

eFc1XFfl91ETPwP0oKe-3Q.text: We wanted to get Indian food when in London and this did not disappoint! The portions were a bit small but we got some appetizers which were really good.Definitely go for the garlic naan! They have a lot of great vegetarian options as well and everything is very reasonably priced.The area the restaurant is in isn't the best but we enjoyed it!

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian curry with garlic naan

WjZMFOiG8NdjQ9d6Bqkl9A.text: A fantastic, no-fuss curry - 10 minute walk from Aldgate East.This place is pretty big, no booking needed. It's BYOB and takes card. It's a really basic cafe style place but the service was really quick and very friendly. And the food was incredible; just have a look in the kitchen as you go in - busy kitchen making a lot of huge pans of curry so the food comes very quickly. The portions are also huge. There were 3 of us including 1 vegetarian. We shared poppadoms, 2 starters; (onion bhaji & paneer tikka). Then 2 mains (one chickpea and one okra), a rice and 2 naan. We could barely finish it all if we'd ordered one each I wouldn't have made it out the place. All of it was so different and delicious. And it came to £10 each including a tip. Ridiculous. Will without doubt go back there again. I think it would also be great with big groups so you can try everything and all bring your own drinks.

5TKaemy2P0BUJyXBd7H-bg.text: Came here for our first introduction to Indian food. We really enjoyed everything we had. Had a number of appetizers for a really reasonable price. Would definitely go back. It is BYO as well.

aJltvba0wDBycgMGnhjszQ.text: I will make it easy for you - 'Original Lahor Kebab House'  easily qualifies to be one the best Indian food experience I have had outside India. To give some background on our experience - I live in US and recently traveled to London on Vacation with my partner. I have been to England before, so I knew that there are some good Indian restaurants. After having been to many Americanised Indian restaurants in US, I was very much looking forward to eat some authentic food. We stayed near East Aldgate station in London and we planned to get there and try an Indian restaurant nearby. Except when we were actually there, the neighborhood had so many Indian restaurants to choose from, we weren't sure which one to choose. But after poring over so many reviews in various websites, we decided on 'Original Lahore Kebab house'. (The restaurant is also just walking distance from whitechapel neighborhood).The restaurant is not much to look at from outside and inside but boy do they make some tasty spicy food. You don't need any reservation, they have plenty of space inside with lot of tables. The place does get quiet noisy when they are busy but that's a minor inconvenience for me. You are not going to bring a first date here for sure. We ordered, 1) Saag Gosht2) Chicken Karahi3) Garlic naan4) Jug of Mango Lassi***Mango lassi - You can order either by Glass or by Jug; and obviously, ordering by Jug gives better value for money as you kind of get 5 glasses worth of Lassi for three glasses price. My partner is kind of a mango lassi freak, so we ordered the jug even though it was too much for two. One thing to note here - the lassi is quiet sweet and creamy without any hint of sourness. Traditionally, the lassis are made from curd that are at least bit sour. Don't mistake me, we loved the mango lassi here but if you are someone who is not totally sold on completely sweet lassis, you may want to get just a glass. ***Chicken Karahi comes in small tava, oily and spicy red - you know, like how you usually get Chicken Karahi. We even asked for extra spicy and they gave us finger licking, eye watering, lips quivering spicy food. Perfection. But seriously, they could do with less oil though. ***Saag Gosht - It was our favorite dish of the day. Spinach and goat meat works so well together and add some naan to the mix, you got yourself a heavenly meal! MUST TRY!Also, the food came out pretty fast. As for service, they may not come to your table and actively smiling and asking if you are okay, but if you ask something they usually make sure you are covered. Pretty efficient overall. If you are in the neighborhood of whitechapel or east aldgate, check this place out - it's totally worth a visit!

f4XXPDCDFXVQNT1drKYvYw.text: Whilst my dal had a tasty and spicy flavour, it was still not as flavourful as it could have been. Also, I found it somewhat hilarious that before I ordering, I asked the waiter whether the dish was spicy and he said no and shook his head no. The roti I ate with it was fine. My husband and friend got the chicken biryani and both expressed disappointment the dish wasn't chicken chunks but rather chicken drumsticks with little meat. The service was attentive at the beginning, and gradually declined to standard ignoring-you-as-long-as-possible London.

FxN3CBfmFCvpz4_rnQveXA.text: Any list that tries to cover the best eateries in London and does not mention Lahore is not to be trusted. This is the best food in London. Period. And this is not just me talking. I've taken my workmates here several times. And I'm yet to find a palate that does not accept the food here as the best.The meal must start with poppadums and a pitcher of mango lassi. Then comes the meat and carbs: karahi gosht, karahi kebabs, haleem, dry lamb, dal tarka, and mince curry. And for the breads you should get the garlic naan and peshwari naan. However full you are after all of this, you have to still get the keema biryani. You're well covered for desserts too--ras malai, kulfi, and the gulab jamun. The best part is no matter how busy the place is, you'll get served super fast. Which is why it is the best for when you're feeling especially ravenous. Final word--of you live in London, go here.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Mountain of papads
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

7bwpeyW5ffrJKVAbgAV3cg.text: Everything was a bit too spicy for my liking (I admit that my tolerance for spicy food is low) and the waiter was not that helpful. We had a large group and you could tell they resented us for wanting to move some tables together. Despite the spicyness, it was still tasty.The mango lassi was the highlight of the night. My friend from China who had never tried it before was converted. Be aware though that it is a large expensive pitcher, not just a glass.(they dont communicate this to you)

NG7M7nMkL278RBraJP7VyA.text: I really want to write a long winded review but shan't. Lahore is the place to go to if you want authentic Indian food! Of south east origin, and growing up in a country where you savour all kinds of food due to its unique and quirky multi ethnicity, you can take my word for it. It's good, really good. However this is not a place if you want smiley waiters and small talks with the staff, it's attentive and they get it sorted out for you with efficiency and then leave you to it.  Come on people, time to try Lahore!

r2AR9p-S3PZArgX2BXSW2Q.text: THE best curry in London.  This was not a quote from me but from two of the guys standing out front having a cigarette.  let's just say that the place looks very unassuming from the outside. Well from the inside as well. In fact a few of the people in our group decided they did not want to try the place because it looks as it does. Their loss!  seriously though this was probably the best Indian food that I have had in my life. Most places to get Currys that I have been too just don't make it properly. Sometimes you get a good one and this was certainly that experience.The service in the restaurant just can't be beat either. You ask for something and it's there almost before you can finish your sentence. On top of that the guys were really helpful and always in a good mood.I won't go down the list of everything we ordered because with a group of 15 like we had there was a lot. I tried most of what was on the table and can't say that anything was bad. There was a few that stood out but just choose what you normally like and you won't be disappointed. This is on my must go to list for London.

b6TGi6g0GMCpHOgtxQzxVA.text: Got the lamb jalfrezi, two seekh kebab, garlic naan and order of rice for two ppl.  Wait was 5 mins.  Yummy food.  Lamb was tasty without being too gamey.  Kebab was slightly spicy, compliments the curry.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Garlic naan
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Seekh kebab
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb jalfrezi

Pwt00G2KHK5YTX-GRxc6ww.text: Having read previous reviews I was expecting great food and less than great service. Instead, we got great service but less than great food. Obviously it's personal opinion but I thought the lamb chops (mentioned by so many as being wonderful) were tough and overdone. The lamb curry and karahi chicken were okay but nothing special (again, the lamb was tough). A mixed vegetable curry we also ordered was kind of tasteless and there wasn't much of it. On the other hand, the chilli naan and vegetable samosas were both very good. The sweet lassi was okay but noticeably inferior to the same drink I've been served elsewhere. Ambience wasn't enjoyable (it was nearly empty when we arrived but soon became crowded and very noisy). But, as I mentioned, the service was fine: the man who served us was very pleasant and helpful.Price-wise, I thought it was a tad expensive, certainly for the quality. On the other hand, meat is a relatively expensive ingredient, so I suppose it is to be expected that meat-based dishes are more expensive than vegetable-based ones. Not sure about the quality of the meat here, though, or whether it was just overcooking that spoiled it.

67ZmWmqAVoyCOEpdS2PyBg.text: Wow. Can't believe I've been missing out on this place. Some of the best authentic curry I've had. This place has a hole-in-the-wall type feel, don't expect anything fancy. Walking right by it outside, I was upset thinking the place was closed, as I couldnt really see anything going on through the glass window, or hear a sound. I walked around the corner to the side entrance, and slowly crept through the door. Suddenly, I was transformed to a whole other atmosphere. A busy kitchen cooking and sizzling, laughter and chatter from the dining room - it was fairly packed! The seating area is large, and we were seated straight away. After realizing the place is BYOB, I ran off to the off-license next door and grabbed some beers! We ordered curries that were specials for the weekend - the dry lamb, lamb chop curry (friday only) and the chicken curry. All were spectacular, and each had its own real distinct flavour. For starters we ordered the seekh kebab and the masala fish. While the fish was tasty, I recommend sticking to the grilled meats. So. Damn. Good. The butter naan was a hot buttery pillow of heaven. GET IT. Definitely will be returning!

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken curry
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Dry lamb
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chop curry (fridays only)

LJFbYAgpIDqcazmDZH5YiA.text: An olde favorite that hasn't changed its menu much. The dining area is a little shinier. We loved the jalfrezi and paneer.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

z4uDsRIQBovwV9J5p19aGw.text: My favorite Pakistan restaurant in my London adventure so far.  It's kitchen cafe style, no particular decor or notable atmosphere and the waiters rarely speak.  So your thinking why come here?The food is outstanding and not expensive.  From very tasty and tender lamb chops, mutton tikka, delicious onion bhajia to great mains like chicken korma, dry meat and king prawn curry.  Add garlic nan and rice and you will be quickly finding excuses to come again.My favorites so far are lamb chops and chicken korma.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb Chops

X-wBBlHvYXzE3Khx_Rlo6Q.text: Was visiting London from the USA. Wanted to eat Indian in the city but didn't want something fancy. Found this place in Yelp and tried it out. Great food with good prices. There is a liquor store next door where you can get your beer or wine and bring it in. Must try the kebabs and the lamb chopps. Great place. Will be back again when in London.

Hc9zLWRqjDFK9ctrVA8ibg.text: I popped down here from Whitechapel to buy some takeout dinner for me and my wife. The restaurant decor looks basic, but I was most impressed by the food.I ordered the chicken tikka masala and the mattar paneer. I got us some biryani rice, a garlic naan and a couple of cokes to have them with. When I opened the bag of treats back where we were eating dinner, I found a bonus salad and a yoghurt dip.The chicken tikka masala was hotter than I had expected. My lips were burning a bit so I relied on a coke to balance it out. I really should have had this with the yoghurt dip; I expect that the combination would have worked well, but I didn't try this until right at the end. The chicken itself was succulent.The mattar paneer was a new thing for me. It is a mild curry of cheese cubes and peas in a mild sauce. My wife and I both liked this.The naan was bready and well seasoned, but I was too full to finish it.The meal was great value at just over £20. I learnt that they have special dishes which are only available on some days of the week. The guy taking my order at the restaurant recommended the lamb chops curry which you can only get on Fridays. I think this place will be worth another try for that one.

LpflaiVQxk9iqiR1JCeVKg.text: I'm a big fan of the no-frills attitude here at Lahore: you come (& maybe you have to queue), you eat & drink and then you go home with a belly full of Punjabi goodness. It's that easy to make me happy.Here's my tips for you:- try to go early on a weekend evening (around 6:30ish or 7) as you won't have to queue up then!- if you want to drink alcohol, you must bring your own alcohol (as there are multiple BYOB restaurants in this area, all the off-licence shops have well-stocked fridges ;-)- the menu can get quite overwhelming and so far every time I've been here, I've ordered different things. However, you can't go wrong with the lamb chops (a must) and I also highly recommend the Chana Masala- do take your time and place a few orders first and then another set of dishes; the waiters don't love it, but they just have to suck it up ;-)Hope you'll enjoy this as much as I always do.

ZXH8jZJpqiAobvmrufpFkg.text: We were recently in London and had to have Pakistani food...this place was recommended by our Uber driver. So happy we came here - the food was delicious and reasonably priced! Service was good - we told him we wanted one dish that wasn't too spicy so he recommended chicken korma to go with our other dishes and wow it was so good/sweet. Restaurant is byob so we went to store across street...not good selection so I would recommend bringing your own if you can. Definitely recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

X6rjot1KCalSMXo3ChJXkQ.text: This busy, massive and iconic Pakistani restaurant is worth the visit.  If I were rating just my entree, it would be five stars. I loved my keema curry, which was perfectly spiced. I was less enamored with the lamb chop appetizer, which was over cooked. The service was also problematic as we waited over 15 minutes from receiving our bill to being able to pay with a credit card.

IbK-Fcjr8MppALmMec5M_Q.text: Today we had the lamb starter, a lonely chicken samosa, the beef biryani, the cheese naan,and the the chicken tikka masala. The lamb was good but like everything else we had was secretly spicy. Not like an in your face spicy but like that one weird neighbor staring at you over your backyard fence, it just creeps up on you. When ordering the chicken samosa I just assumed that it would be a plate of small ones but they literally just bring you one...so ask for multiples if that's what you want or just sing one is the loneliest number when you get your one samosa on a plate. But it was good even though the dough was a bit too thick which made it difficult to chew. The beef biryani was good, brought to the table super hot and was so spicy for me personally that it made my lips swell. Dinner and free lip plumping, what a deal. The chicken tikka masala was also good and the chicken was super tender. The star of the show for me was the cheese naan. The cheese was actually inside the two layers of naan instead of on top like I assumed. It was tender, cheesy, but not overbearing. All in all, the food was good and you won't be mad at it.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka masala
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Beef Biyrani
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. the cheesy naan bread

8rKFoY3QBbGjo5BJGgMiGg.text: I recall this place having Amazing Kebabs. Maybe some of the best I ever had.the curries weren't very memorable. But that was about 10yrs ago. Decided to finally go back. Was a bit disappointed with the Kebabs as the chicken tikka were completely bone dry and overcooked. The Lamb chops were decent.But was quite surprised with how good the curries and breads were.Overall - can't beat a place where 10 people eat like kings and spend 23GBP each (not counting BYOB beers from the "Off-license" next door).One word of warning - large groups are seated upstairs... which means you maybe seating next to 30 people on a "Stag" chanting and chugging and being obnoxious as is to be expected with such a thing... but definitely changes your noise level altogether.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chops left, kebabs right

fMl7EK2eMmHD3YrXZZZtZQ.text: Went here couple of times in a group. The best thing about this place is it is BYOB which means that you can buy your booze next door and bring it in.There is nothing much to write about the decor or service as it is just functional which is OK for a place of this nature. From a food perspective, being brutally honest, I personally found the food to be just average  compared to some of the other similar Pakistani or Indian eateries I have been to. Food is served hot and is flavoursome but not exceptional. May be I felt this way because I am extremely picky when it comes to the sub-continental cuisine and don't get impressed easily. It is definitely a good place to hang out in a group drinking and eating variety of meat dishes and they do have a non-rushed service so you end up having a really nice time. The food is also reasonably priced for this part of London plus getting the booze from the store means you don't burn a hole in your pocket. Don't  go here for the food alone as you might be a tad disappointed.

quMpQWBWTsxis2nf7f6j3w.text: Good food, we had kabobs and naan. Mango lassi was alright, not the best I have had. But this place is open late and it was packed! In my opinion, the food at Giftos in Southend tastes the best! I am a tourist from the States and I have to say London has the best desi food : )

uixTL03Eornb7k6B597HJA.text: After seeing action Bronson (rapper) recommend this place while being in London we said hey why not go and try their lamb chops. We were in soho for happy hour after a days of traveling so we said why not go and try it. We took about a 35-45 minute über ride to get here and it did not disappoint. It is byob so we ran to the liquor store and got ourselves a bottle and indulged in some great great food. The lamb chops were amazing! So tender so juicy. The rest of the food was amazing as well but I'll be back for the lamb chops.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

l_5wMKB2hMma7jEGJYcu6A.text: Much better than nearby Tayyabs which seems to.have the glory without the taste. The best Curry ever. Lamb chops, chicken Tikka, spinach, aubergine and dahl curries. Just delicious and fast well priced service. Excellent..

eZAerGKTUNOuj_I7fRDSqg.text: Honestly hugely disappointed. I heard so much about this place but I've had better elsewhere. We ordered Paya, Nihari, Karahi Gosht and Seekh kebab. The Karahi was just a regular lamb curry with a slight runny tomato base texture nothing close to a karahi dish from Pakistan.  Paya was ok but the spices they used were so over powering the pungent paya flavour didn't come through. Seekh kebab were somewhat burnt and dry not juicy enough. Nihari - there was just gristle fat on the bone no solid meat and no dressing (traditionally sliced ginger and coriander) Naan was really good especially the Rogani naan and our waiter was very friendly hence the two stars. I guess it's a hit and miss depending on what dish you order. I think I would've been happy with a keema naan and possibly lamb chops as they looked good. My search for authentic Lahore Nihari, Paya and karahi is still on.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Nihari as served.
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Seekh Kebab as served
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb Karahi

s-CNaWReXZ79CjPRhmwb_g.text: This place is Indian or Nepal restaurant I visited mostly for the first time in London, so this should be some criteria in the future. At first I was a little bit surprised by no alcohol sold but soon I bought outside. Curry and nun were good not so impressive but not so bad.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

mWjQXAiM2u4BOxf-CoVMCQ.text: We ended up at Lahore on the recommendation of friends who live in London. We were craving top notch Pakistani or Indian food and this was the recommendation from all of them. This placed was PACKED on a Thursday night! Local Pakistanis and visitors alike. We ended up having to wait a short while for a table. This is BYOB and there is a convenient bottle shop right next door with plenty of beers and vino. The service was a bit slow - however the food made up for it!! Papadum - very good, hard to go wrong. Would have been nice with some accompaniments Veggie samosa - great pastry! very light on the filling though - needed more. Reminded me of Christmas from all the all spice. Onion Bhajia - very good. This is the style where all the individual pieces are battered, instead of an Onion ball. Heavy on the chickpea flourSeekh (Lamb) Kebab - exceptional flavor, great spices. Juicy kebab - not dry at all.Garlic and Peshaweri naan breads - a bit disappointed in the naan. Not as pillow-y fluffy as I'm used to/enjoy Chicken Tikka Masala - flavors were perfect. Really spicy - yummm!!The meat itself was a tiny bit dry, but could just be that it's breast meat, which usually dries out faster. Lamb Jalfrezi - very succulent slow cooked lamb pieces. The sauce was not as good as the Chicken Tikka Masala. Equally as spicy though!!Highly recommended for authentic Pakistani food!! Excited to go back and try even more dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Onion bahjia
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Veggie samosa
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb kebab

kJzJ1wvZk3-sxcj9S8d3NQ.text: Maybe it was because I got takeaway, but I was disappointed especially after hearing so much about this place. I ordered the lamb curry and naan bread. Firstly, it's not cheap. Over £10 for this standard takeaway. The curry was delicious and the lamb soft and tender. Naan was OK. But I felt like it was average overall, and I've had my fair share of Indian and Pakistani food.

PD8G-yltmwX-f-wOxbHomg.text: Go! And bring lots of beer and/or wine with you. Dinner here was truly awesome. It's a BYOB (they do not serve alcohol) and should you forget to pick up something there is a little store at the corner which has a pretty solid selection. Be sure to try the mixed grill. The lamb chops were really good and we had around 5 curries that were all pretty good too. One tip which I'll pass on is that you will leave smelling like the food so feel free to dress down or plan your post dinner activities accordingly.

ifdytmvISMJGXbPUtWYPmQ.text: What can one say about this iconic restaurant. Their brashness, loud-ness & untidyness is an attitude.....not to mention the food itself. After the food a must have is their Kheer which is the perfect ending to the orgy of meats that you have just downed.

aRxgGiZyp_nnkJtiXhBbkA.text: This is the real OG Pakistani cuisine. If you're visiting this neighborhood, you'll instantly recognize the familiar shops and eateries that are associated with the Indo-Pak subcontinent. This was a little out-of-the-way, but entirely worth it. When we entered the restaurant I was surprised to see more tourists vs. the usual local crowd. We were then greeted by a waiter, seated, and brought a menu with quite a few options. Every item on the menu was very reasonably priced, and ranged from €6-15. We ordered the mixed grill which consisted of chicken tikka, lamb tikka and seekh kabobs. We also ordered a bowl of Nihari (traditional spicy beef stew) along with plenty of naan. In terms of quality, I've never eaten Pakistani food this good. The meats were all very succulent and tender, and the Nihari was savory as well as spicy. For the spice level, I was amazed and impressed to see that many non-Pakistani/Indian people handled it in the restaurant with far less water than us  For a family of five, we ended up spending something close to €10 per person which was very reasonable considering the quantity as well as quality. 5/5 would highly recommend.

iHcZHbxVt0fUs4GAPEwENw.text: I wouldn't have found this place if it wasn't for my Indian friends. So a round of applause for my friend, Uday, for bringing me to this fabulous place. The food was amazing and when my tongue stops burning, I will be back for more. This is as authentic as it can be in London for Indian food. It's not fine dinning. None of that fusion stuff from Dishroom (which is also nice btw). We dined on the second floor, which is a bit more noisy. But as soon as we walked in, it felt like I was in India again. You can't go wrong with the menu. It's all good. My only recommendation is get the Nahari, which is stewed lamb knuckles in spicy curry. It was to die for. Look out for the weekend specials too. No questions about it, coming back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chops!
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

ihNSFUPNvGlw47szgJ9PuA.text: Excellent: Kebabs and Mango LassiAbove Average: (not food related) - the pricing and quicknessAverage: Samosas and Lamb ChopsSlightly Below Average: Curry's - too oilyBelow Average: Service - every server I saw and that assisted us did not speak English. You also had to wave them down if you needed anything as they would not come to your table to see how things areIf this is your only option then it's fine. It's definitely better than most spots but if you have time to travel to other spots then you should.

GG2rn3wAW1NpcpTBG7ehFA.text: Perhaps I went on an off night,  but I was sorely disappointed by this popular desi joint. The service was terrible-- rude, inattentive, and outright condescending. The food was fine, but by no means good-- which was shocking giving its reputation. The naan was not hot or bubbly. We ordered chicken jalfraizi, but were given a karhai. When I told our server we had been given the wrong dish, he told me that it was in fact chicken jalfraizi-- which was a lie... either he couldn't be bothered to correct the mistake, or they were out of chicken jalfraizi. The karhai was fine but not tasty, and the attitude that came with the incorrect order left more of a bad taste in our mouths. Too many better options in London, can't recommend this place.

SYLjDzQMDY0Qx_T-jKkJKw.text: Reasonably priced, quick & attentive service. The meats were all very good but the Lamb chops stood out- as good as advertised.On the spicy side. Biryani and the rest of the food was ok.Would definitely visit again if in the area but wouldn't say it's worth traveling from another part of town for it.

wPkoSj-pciwVjvS-kMmQ9g.text: I came here on a quiet weekday afternoon to try their lamb chops, which I'd heard were something really special. I felt let down. The chops were ok but certainly no better than I've had in numerous other curry houses. I get the feeling the Lahore is now an institution that's been matched or even overtaken by a number of its competitors.

nFZL4UOWWR0lSVqLbXO7zg.text: The food here is delicious. Especially the lamb chops. The best ive had from anywhere at anytime. The food was ordered by a fellow diner  who loves the place and there was so much variety. We had vegetarian dishes, meat dishes, rice dishes, samosas, sauces, A mango smoothie that was like comfort food and that is its purpose if the food is too hot. The dishes are hot and spicy  but not unbearable. For me it was the right balance. The staff are aplenty, Its a big restaurant with lots of tables, an upstairs as well. Great for groups..........

Ds10VfpAKqI7dqC7PiwyIQ.text: chicken tikka, saag paneer, regular naan, lassi, was out of korma curry and fish curry.  not better than what we get in sunnyvale, but nice that they made everything with some spice to it.  even though it's not comparing the same thing, I enjoyed going to Tayyabs more.

sC_ZJxZWZO8JMSfp6jqH6g.text: Great food, decent price, served quickly... I really like the place to get food quickly with a group of friends. The food is really tasty and I always leave with my stomach on the brink of explosion... Great place to go if you are in the Aldgate/Whitechapel area.

0Vmq_RkaU7Q4MyDNFsrqmA.text: ... wait, don't ask for the bill just yet, order a kulfi each, they come in mango, pistachio and malay (plain/milk) flavours.  Wonderful Indian / Pakistani / South Asian ice cream on a stick.

UfZahCbZwn7S2mVFx_RE2Q.text: Finally after many years of not being able to make it over there on many London trips.  The best kabobs I've had and had been dying to return to.  Curries are good but highlight are the kabobs, all of them, the lamb chops were very good as well.

WUouruw-29_taYCHFrlzBw.text: The best in the area. Whatever the time... Whatever you want....LKH is on the case. Great food and great atmosphere. One of the owners sons treats me like a long lost brother when I go. The food was so nice my dog  was salivating whilst watcjing me eat my takeaway from here. Since then she has become addicted to the chicken biryanu from this place...forget pedegree chum or ceasers....this is the dog's bol......

DXgzOnoacvI1yDjH_cw5KQ.text: Awesome. Simple, tasty, and quick. The closest thing to Pakistani food outside of Pakistan.

7_xY9uZjUkLIbUHqXDEEwg.text: The Ritz it is not.  Very plain decor, very abrupt but polite service.  Excellent food and reasonably priced.  As I have read in other reviews, they bring you salad without asking and then charge you for it.  Not the custom in USA but apparently an accepted practice here.  I ordered the chicken kebab roll and it was delicious and very large.  I shared it with my friend.  The Daal Chicken was beautifully spiced, a little on the hot side.  Rice was extra.  If you are nearby or can take the bus, I think it is worth the trip.  I wish I ate lamb because it smelled and looked great.  My friend had the lamb curry and she was very pleased.  The garlic nan was fresh and tasty.

vG8n9IJ97UJ1fTOg-m6L9Q.text: I'm fairly new to London and a big Indian/Pakistani food fan so i was delighted to find this place. Its food is varied, cheap and delicious. Lots of vegitarian options (around 5 pounds) and lots of great meet dishes to (7.50 on average) (try the grilled lamb chops). Also remember this place is BYOB (there is a bottle shop next door with fairly good selection). Also great desserts (carrot pudding with ice cream and pistachio Popsicles are great)

C24fAnMI4pq1oJot1-avhg.text: Firstly, this place is not trendy. There is absolutely no interior decoration, no back ground music or candle lights. Secondly, there is always, always a queue in to Lahore Kebab-House.  No table reservations!The place has became pretty famous for its authentic Pakistani cuisine. The only thing I was wondering is the word kebab..as you don't immediately think of fancy dining once you hear that.
