But I was glad to discover that the food was amazing, tasty, and also the vegetarian options were good. The food is also very spicy and the waiter though it was well funny when we struggled with our chilli, but was kind enough to bring us some extra plain yoghurt.The place is very lively and as mentioned, always packed, but the service was so kind and fast that it is worth the wait. The customer's are a mixed bag with entire families with kids running around and business man's in their suits -everyone just seems to love the place!

gjMdn3Y7-0w6DT4etphNHw.text: Big fan of dark curries and I have no problems with "hole in the wall" type places but was expecting a lot more given the reviews. Was a bit tipped off by the general sloppiness, also my rice portion seemed recycled from previous guests. Ok, it's not expensive but you can get that next door, too.

2q38eX6rVbxZHFp-d95qsQ.text: I believe I have become spoiled. I had heard that this place was excellent, even better than Tayyab's. So of course I had to go. I did think it was very good, but I think Tayyab's is better. We ordered the mixed grill. Lamb chops - good but a bit dry. Chicken: surprisingly great, and so moist! The seekh kebab was also great. The lamb biryani was good, but wasn't quite what I was used to. It had a tomato-based sauce mixed in with it. The other curries were done well. But I am spoiled.The restaurant is BYOB, and there is an off-license right across the street.Gluten-free notes: With this type of cuisine, there is a lot you can eat. No naan.

stJ73yfo45c8uhladj_8NA.text: Hands down my favorite Indian spot in London. Whenever we visit we try and go there. Never, ever been let down by anything I've eaten there. And always very reasonable. Of course, living in the colonies may have made me curry hungry, but even when I lived there I loved going there.Fast service, plenty of friendly waiters and a crazy bustling vibe. Well worth a wait if you have to.

e6u-FPX5jU71I_3il3otOw.text: I can't say much more then excellent food, It used to be the place for city workers at lunch and dinner time but now is now mainly family.The decor is not very impressive but its clean and the food more then makes up for it. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend to anyone and know they could order with there eyes shut and still get an amazing meal!Great also is they do not serve alcohol but do allow you to Bring Your Own Booze, they have 3 off licences neighbouring so no worries if you forget to bring any.

k8wnkypHfCo8H8fPTmxc6w.text: been a few times now. was better a couple years ago, but still an excellent curry in london. grilled lamb chops, piles of onion bhaji and good spicy curry. BYOB is good too. excellent value

Vin3MjU41FCF0NyqPkb9qg.text: Whew, to think I almost missed this place.  We went on a rainy Friday night (fine english weather?)   Standing across Commercial Road we thought for a minute that the place had gone out of business since all the windows of the store on the corner of Commercial and Umberston had shades drawn all the way down.  Luckily some very satisfied looking patrons came out the front door on Umberston Street and we realized our mistake.  There's also a big huge sign with a giant arrow pointing around the corner that we somehow missed as well lol.Anyway, from there we a walked right in and were seated immediately.  The place is huge so there wasn't any problem getting a table even on a busy Friday night.  The joint is clearly all about the food as others have mentioned it is crowded, bright and noisy.  The service is probably not the best either but they do get the job done.  They also brought us an extra curry by mistake which we hadn't ordered but left it on the table on the house.We had lamb kebabs, chicken korma with naan and rice pilau.  Everything was delicious.  With the extra curry they brough out it was more food than we could eat but it was so good we managed to finish it all anyway.  Definitely some of the best curries I've ever had.  The Mango Lassi was also excellent, I wish I knew about the pitchers before I went!  If I had been able to eat anymore I would've tried the lamb chops, both tables next to us ordered them and they looked and smelled amazing.  After the food itself, the best part was the bill at the end, just over 20 quid and we both left stuffed!  Will definitely return next time I'm in London!

MchkApHXak1svJt7JmGczA.text: UPDATED.Visited the commercial road branch last sunday, had a nice lamb kebab wrap which only cost £2.50, was quite spicy, brought a pitcher of mango lassi for £7, although they don't advertise the pitcher size on the menu you should order a pitcher it's cheaper then buying a glass for £3.50. My friends had lamb and rice which they said was very tasty but spicy, my other friend had a curry which was very tasty.Highly recommend this place.I go to their Hendon branch my old boss and workmates use to take me here for lunches!Each time i try something new and their food is just delicious!I bit too spicy i tend to break out in a sweat sometimes eating the curries!

7EaftlWU6rnTjzQ8033p3A.text: so great. some of the best i've had, and possibly THE best.we went there on vacation in march. we loved everything. lambchops, naan, samosa, 2 entrees - all amazing.the only thing that was lacking was the atmosphere. it's incredibly casual. almost dive-y. so i wouldn't recommend it if you're looking for atmosphere. however, if you're looking for amazing pakistani food, this is the place.

photos.caption: Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom. the line is worth it. trust me.
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Original Lahore Kebab House - London, United Kingdom

5tKgFFeU_lGZegYgvJxPpg.text: Ended up at Lahore because the line at Tayyabs was out of control (surprise, surprise). The atmsosphere leaves a lot to be desired-- I really have a problem with the flat screen tvs having Eurosport playing the whole time.  Ended up in the upstairs which is like a cafeteria hall.  Decor is non-existent.  The lambchops were definitely the highlight as was the mixed grill appetizer.  Grilled meats just might be their speciality.  The curries were unimpressive and I am kind of a naan-snob--I like it to be hot and soft and just bursting with yumminess.  I felt the naan was dry and stiff.  If you need to fill up on curry, probably a decent choice, but if you are looking for a food experience, take on the queue at Tayyabs....

RszzgTI8Vt_dK2V-htmwRQ.text: Delicious food... Order the chicken tiki as a starter definitely- juicy and saffrony.  The dry lamb curry was gorgeous and not too hot.

mInnD2D9LwECst1MgIV0WQ.text: When my dad was a student this was a hole in the wall kebab kitchen that was occasionally evacuated because of the smoke. They bought a place to stand out of the rain, added garden furniture (since replaced) and after its discovery by "Time Out" they expanded and refurbished entirely to deal with the crowds. Thankfully the food is unchanged, although the kitchen no longer catches on fire, and the service remains friendly if chaotic.I've never had their vegetarian options and probably never will (my dad would disappove). The only sensible way to eat here is to order a pile of kebabs and lots of roti or naan. They also have excellent curries but beware that the sauce is where the really hot chili lurks, masochists should try a spoonful from the bottom. A mango lassi is a good counterpoint to the hot stuff.The place is completely unpretentious, cheap, fast and tasty. Hopefully it stays the same for another thirty years.

LFxqoAY4KpYo_03IbdL4Gg.text: Lahore Kebab House is an excellent no-frills byo restaurant. Yes, the decor leaves a lot to be desired, but, head there in the evening and the place is usually packed - atmosphere sorted.When I visited we ordered only starters and kebabs. The lamb chops were divine, if a little too spicy. The samosas were a bit disappointing, but the kebabs more than made up for it. And the chicken wings were pretty damn good too. The kebab meat was served on massive plates, with a tower of pitta-like bread to wrap with. All in all truly delicious.I suppose one of the best things about this place is the fact that it's byo. Also, there's a small shop just opposite that serves large bottles of Tiger and Kingfisher for that authentic experience. The waiters were very helpful and even kept our bottles in their fridge to keep them nice and cold. The best part of the meal was the bill. For five people eating starters and a couple of kebabs, the whole thing came to £12 a head. Could not believe it. Total bargain, will be going again soon, even if means venturing a bit off the beaten track.

_TaztvzzZ8IVX3G40Z7OPQ.text: Wicked mate!! simple, the focus here is on the food, you have to try the Okra dish i took a mate there and insisted on going back!good for large tables they will accommodate, you might have to queue, if you go on a fri night you will have to wait regardless. this a BYOB and theres an offy that makes a killing on booze!

YCyV34ntCCJJMgdIlWIBhw.text: I've never had a bad meal, check that, never had a bad dish here.Inexpensively priced, huge-portioned plates and bowls of deciousness are served here by courteous waitstaff in this down-an-alley establishment.Definitely go for the meats - tender and abundant combined with yummy sauces and spices and grilled to perfection.

urE1hVmpKxI7CakuwMhbaw.text: If you like spicy food, and you come to the Lahore House, you'd best bring an Indian or a Pakistani or someone else of South Asian origin with you, or you might come away from here pretty underwhelmed.At least, based on my own dining experiences here, that's my theory.I'd heard raves about this place for years - mainly from Pakistani and Punjabi friends - and couldn't wait to try it out.  The first time I went was with my (very white, very blonde) family.  We're all veterans of South Asian cuisine and can eat raw chopped chilies with the best of them... but wanting to sample the greatest they had to offer, we turned our fates over to the hands of our server and asked, "What do you recommend we order?"Big mistake.  I'm sure he took us for a bunch of pansy-stomached curry novices because what he brought us was *dismal.*  No spice.  No flavour.  No heat.  BLAND.  Perhaps the most bland sorry-excuse-for-spicy-cuisine I've ever had.Needless to say, I thought all of my friends were crazy for proselytizing about Lahore, and had no desire to go back.  Then one day, just a little against my will, I was dragged back by an Indian friend of mine.  And?  The difference in the food was like night and day.  This was marvelously spiced - savory, delectable... I wanted to eat *more.*  It was so much better than my first experience I could hardly believe this was the same restaurant.  It was as if the fact that my friend had ordered in Hindi had put a spell of addictive flavour on the food.Afterwards, all I could think was: Hmmm... I'm never coming back here without someone who can speak the waiter's language and tell him that even though it may not look like it, I really can handle the "real deal."

boReyFnv8ZqDDadj4PW8AA.text: Lahore Kebab House is a welcome break for East Londoners who are tired of the crap that is regularly passed off as Indian food in Brick Lane. Its not a kebab shop as most Londoners would imagine a kebab shop to be. Its a proper restaurant and LKH serves some of the best and most affordable Indian (primarily Punjabi) food in London.First let me be clear that this place has its negatives. Its not ideal for a business meeting, its absolutely dreadful as a date place and its too noisy for a quite meal. In fact its good for just one thing ... to go and eat :)Try the seekh kebab for starter. At just 1 pound, its an awesome bargain ... and also tasty. LKH doesn't serve alcohol, so we always order a pitcher of thick mango lassi (strongly recommended). You get ~ 6 glasses of the stuff at a price of 2. The food is well cooked and well presented. The service usually ranges from average to very good (depends on who is the waiter serving you). Once the person serving us got us a wrong dish. Not only did he get us the correct one, he left the earlier dish, didn't charge for it, and also refused a tip that day. Not an incident one can easily forget.The gravies are oily ... probably a bit too oily for my liking ... but i guess thats just the price you pay for tasty Indian food. That makes this place non-repeatable, unlike some of its competitors.I suggest you should reserve a table if you are going on a weekend evening. Even with two floors of dining space, most people still end up waiting for some time at least on arriving.There is no special item that i can recommend. The menu is very standard, and they make most of the stuff well. So just go along with your usual preference.LKH is unbelievably good value for money, and hence a must visit for anyone who enjoys cheap,good Indian food.P.S: If any one you ever get a bill of more than 20 pounds per head, just tell me how managed it. Please do :)

lGjM5O1_hXONV7S8nAdsKQ.text: Simply the best Indian in London! My boss, who is Indian took me here once and I've been going there ever since. They don't serve alcohol, but will be happy to open a bottle of wine or a beer for you. There is a little shop right outside the restaurant where everyone goes to buy beers :)

4sxthaUsnjNaPWt4E_l8WQ.text: What's not to love about this gem of a place?! Delicious food (the large amount of Asian diners testify to this). Amazing lamb chops-succulent, char-grilled and tender. Cheap and BYO.

X5HqtN30-JVw0VM4hJKmxA.text: The haleem from this place is a miracle broth - it has ground wheat, lots of chicken and slivers of delightful fresh ginger - fabulous with a squeeze of lemon alongside butter naan. Shame it's only available over weekends!The karahi (chargrilled) and sag (spinach) chicken and lamb dishes are rich, buttery and very authentic, and most of the dishes are eye-wateringly spicy - which is just the way I like it! Great lassis, too.The portions are huge (the haleem is definitely to be shared by two!), and they plied me and my Pakistani flatmate with 'experimental' free main courses. They don't serve alcohol, so intoxicate yourself with the mango/pistachio kulfi icecreams! Alternatively, there's an off-license right across the road.

tP8zwE7hMF73Mov5wE_UXQ.text: It is a bit out of the way, but worth the trek. The friend who introduced me to this place is known for her love of trendy bars, but also for sussing out the most authentic and obscure eateries. Lahore Kebab House certainly qualifies in the slightly obscure category. We were warned only to get starters, but they were more than enough. Each one was about the size of a normal main course in itself. Everything we tried here was delicious, to the extent that you find yourself trying to eat as much as you can, which is not a good tactic as you feel it for hours afterwards, and end up waddling home like a drunken penguin. If you are eating here, remember to bring your own wine. There are a couple of off-licenses nearby, so even if you forget, it is not the end of the world.
